verses.verse: to speak evil of no one, to be peaceable, gentle, showing all humility to all men.
For (1 Cor. 6:11; 1 Pet. 4:3) we ourselves were also once foolish, disobedient, deceived, serving various lusts and pleasures, living in malice and envy, hateful and hating one another.
But when (Titus 2:11) the kindness and the love of (1 Tim. 2:3) God our Savior toward man appeared,
((Rom. 3:20); Eph. 2:4-9) not by works of righteousness which we have done, but according to His mercy He saved us, through (John 3:3) the washing of regeneration and renewing of the Holy Spirit,
(Ezek. 36:26) whom He poured out on us abundantly through Jesus Christ our Savior,
that having been justified by His grace ((Matt. 25:34); Mark 10:17; (Rom. 8:17, 23, 24; Titus 1:2)) we should become heirs according to the hope of eternal life.

(1 Tim. 1:15) This is a faithful saying, and these things I want you to affirm constantly, that those who have believed in God should be careful to maintain good works. These things are good and profitable to men.
(Avoid Dissension) But (1 Tim. 1:4; 2 Tim. 2:23) avoid foolish disputes, genealogies, contentions, and strivings about the law; for they are unprofitable and useless.
(Matt. 18:17) Reject a divisive man after the first and second admonition,
knowing that such a person is warped and sinning, being self-condemned.
(Final Messages) When I send Artemas to you, or (Acts 20:4; Eph. 6:21; Col. 4:7; 2 Tim. 4:12) Tychicus, be diligent to come to me at Nicopolis, for I have decided to spend the winter there.
Send Zenas the lawyer and (Acts 18:24; 1 Cor. 16:12) Apollos on their journey with haste, that they may lack nothing.
And let our people also learn to maintain good works, to meet urgent needs, that they may not be unfruitful.
(Farewell) All who are with me greet you. Greet those who love us in the faith. Grace be with you all. Amen.
(Greeting) Paul, a (Eph. 3:1) prisoner of Christ Jesus, and Timothy our brother, To Philemon our beloved friend and fellow laborer,
to the beloved Apphia, (Col. 4:17) Archippus our fellow soldier, and to the church in your house:
Grace to you and peace from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
(Philemon’s Love and Faith) (Eph. 1:16; 1 Thess. 1:2; 2 Thess. 1:3) I thank my God, making mention of you always in my prayers,
(Eph. 1:15; Col. 1:4; 1 Thess. 3:6) hearing of your love and faith which you have toward the Lord Jesus and toward all the saints,
that the sharing of your faith may become effective (Phil. 1:9; (Col. 1:9; 3:10; James 2:14-17)) by the acknowledgment of ((1 Thess. 5:18)) every good thing which is in you in Christ Jesus.
For we have great joy and consolation in your love, because the hearts of the saints have been refreshed by you, brother.
(The Plea for Onesimus) Therefore, though I might be very bold in Christ to command you what is fitting,
yet for love’s sake I rather appeal to you—being such a one as Paul, the aged, and now also a prisoner of Jesus Christ—
I appeal to you for my son (Col. 4:9) Onesimus, whom I have begotten while in my chains,
who once was unprofitable to you, but now is profitable to you and to me.
